title: How are freedom and determinism related? - Quora

response.answer_text: How are freedom and determinism related? If you look it superficially, it looks like freedom and determinism are the opposite. How can you have a freedom if everything is determined in advance? Well, this is true if you think of freedom as the ability to do anything that you want to do. But, if you can do everything that you want to do, will you experience freedom? Actually not. Think of a person that does not have any obligation, who can follow any caprice that he has. Will that person be a free person? Actually not, he will be a slave to his wimps. Now think of a person who is serving a time in jail for political “crimes”. He may experience far more freedom than his fellow citizens that “follow the rules”. We are used to think of freedom as something that is outside of us, that have been given to us. However, freedom is more of a being a person can have. Two people that live in the same condition can have completely different experience of freedom. To conclude, a thought: is it possible that actually understanding that our world is deterministic, allows us to experience real and complete freedom?

DETERMINISM AND FREEWILL DEFINED Before proceeding further, let’s ensure that all readers at least superficially understand what these terms mean. Determinism is… “…the theory that everything that happens must happen as it does and could not have happened any other way.” [determinism Definition in the Cambridge English Dictionary] “…in philosophy, the theory that all events, including moral choices, are completely determined by previously existing causes. Determinism is usually understood to preclude free will, because it entails that humans cannot act otherwise than they do.” [Determinism | philosophy] Free will is… “…the ability to act and make choices independent of any outside influence.” [free will Definition in the Cambridge English Dictionary] “…in humans, the power or capacity to choose among alternatives or to act in certain situations independently of natural, social, or divine restraints. Free will is denied by some proponents of determinism.” [Free Will] COEXISTENCE OF PARTIAL DETERMINISM AND PARTIAL FREE WILL Freedom and determinism are mutually exclusive if, and only if, we take determinism as absolute and all-inclusive — a presumption against which I argue and present evidence in Joel Lantz's answer to If all our actions are derived from our genetics and our environment/past, is freewill an illusion?. However, if we more realistically consider the following for humans... Partial determinism — SOME (not all) human events, are determined by previously existing causes.Substantial free will — MUCH power or capacity in humans to choose among alternatives or to act in independently of natural, social, or divine restraints....then determinism and free will are not mutually exclusive. Illustration #1Some scientists and philosophers would have us believe that our inherited genomes substantially predetermine our behaviors and destinies; some even think that we should excuse criminal behavior on the basis of supposed genetic determinism. [1] Is that true? The following arguably better illustrates reality: Partial determinism — some person-specific genes we inherit may predispose us toward certain cancers and other diseases, and may make certain behaviors more likely or harder to overcome. One may say that’s partially deterministic.Substantial free will — However, though faulty genetic sequences in our DNA are inherited, and may result from many generations of parentage, the expression of those genes — the epigenetics [2, 3] — is in many cases not. Most importantly, the epigenetics is affected by lifestyle choices:  “The field of epigenetics is quickly growing and with it the understanding that both the environment and individual lifestyle can also directly interact with the genome to influence epigenetic change…There are numerous examples of epigenetics that show how different lifestyle choices and environmental exposures can alter marks on top of DNA and play a role in determining health outcomes.” [3] <Emphases are mine.>  “What you eat, where you live, who you interact with, when you sleep , how you exercise, even aging – all of these can eventually cause chemical modifications around the genes that will turn those genes on or off over time.” [2]Illustration #2 As another example, we all make frequent choices to give in to inclinations (some of which may be harmful to us or others) or to resist. Giving in is the easy way out, and successfully resisting requires proactive free will. Situations and drives beyond our control may influence the difficulty with which we resist certain inclinations/temptations, but ultimately we must exercise free will to successfully resist them. Functional MRI (fMRI) studies of the brain, which detect blood flow in specific areas of the brain, seem widely misused these days to supposedly support the absence of genuine (vs. illusory) free will. See the rebuttal comments and reference in endnote 17 of https://www.quora.com/If-all-our-actions-are-derived-from-our-genetics-and-our-environment-past-is-freewill-an-illusion/answer/Joel-Lantz. Such studies arguably do not legitimately show the absence of free will.However, some such studies support the presence of free will. For example, one such study (performed with appropriate experimental controls) compared fMRI scans of young, healthy male volunteers as they viewed sexually-explicit videos, first before asking the men to deliberately suppress sexual arousal and then after. Some areas of the brain ‘dimmed’ and others ‘lit up’ in the fMRI scans when the subjects mentally suppressed sexual arousal — objectively suggesting free-will inhibition of strong biologically-driven inclinations. [M. Beauregard, J. Lévesque, and P. Bourgouin, Neural Correlates of Conscious Self-regulation of Emotion, Journal of Neuroscience 21 (2001): RC165 (1–6).] What we see here is…Partial determinism — Strong biological sex drives passed down through many generations.Substantial free will — Conscious, proactive efforts to successfully suppress biological sex drives.BOTTOM LINE Degrees of determinism and free will both exist, and we are to some extent influenced by factors beyond our control. But we cannot ultimately blame our choices and destiny on determinism. Again, I suggest reviewing Joel Lantz's answer to If all our actions are derived from our genetics and our environment/past, is freewill an illusion?. The relationship between freedom and determinism is that they are mutually exclusive. Determinism posits that all activity in the universe is both (i) the effect of [all] prior activity, and (ii) the only activity that can occur given the prior activity. That is what is meant by saying that everything is “determined” — it is the inexorable consequence of activity that preceded it. In a deterministic universe, everything that has ever occurred, is occurring, and will occur since the universe came into existence (however that might have occurred) can only occur exactly as it has occurred, is occurring, or will occur, and cannot possibly occur in any different manner. This mandated activity necessarily includes all human action, including all human cognition. Freedom exists when the state of affairs that exists in the universe immediately prior to a human action does not compel all by one action and permits the human to act in an unconstrained manner. Based on the foregoing, if Determinism is true, human beings lack the ability to act in a manner that is not 100% caused by prior activity that is outside of their control, and thereby lack freedom. By the same token, if humans do possess the freedom to act in a manner that is not entirely compelled by prior activity in the universe, then Determinism is false. In the final analysis, Determinism and Freedom simply cannot coexist. Indeed, to posit the coexistence of these two incompatible concepts violates the principle of non-contradiction, which is a bedrock foundation of logic.

Applied to human behaviour, freedom means that you can act according to your preferences, without being coerced or restrained. Some people reflect on this and say: hang on, maybe you’re not really free if you are forced to act by your brain, or by the laws of physics, or by the weight of past events. But this is silly. It is not what is meant by “freedom” in normal parlance. It is like saying that the speed limit on the highway is not really a “limit” because it is possible to exceed it, unlike a real physical limit, like the speed of light. You can redefine words, but ultimately their meaning comes from their usage in the relevant context.

Determinism is the doctrine that everything that happens has a cause and is therefore inevitable. These effects become in their turn the causes of further effects. Thus chains of cause and effect extend through time and space. In science, the discovery by Isaac Newton of the laws of motion and gravitation provided the basis for an entirely mechanistic explanation of the universe. This led the French astronomer Pierre-Simon to assert that it was possible for the mind- if provided with data regarding all the forces operating in the universe, together with information about the mass, dimensions and positions of all objects that lie within it- to work out both the past and future of everything. The 18th-century Scottish philosopher David Hume suggested that causality may be no more than a habit of mind, without any logical validity. In the 20th Century, quantum mechanics has shown that in the realm of subatomic particles, indeterminacy prevails. The fact that determinism appears to deny the existence of free will, and therefore the moral responsibility of individuals for their actions, presents a central problem in ethics. In politics, those on the right tend to emphasize the individual's own responsibility for their condition while those on the left point out that an individual's condition is to a great extent determined by external factors such as environment, education and upbringing.
